problem_text:
Let H be a proper subgroup of a group G and let elements a, b ∈ H have distinct prime orders p, q. Suppose that, for every g ∈ G \ H, the subgroup ⟨a, bg⟩ is a finite Frobenius group with complement of order pq. Does the subgroup generated by the union of the kernels of all Frobenius subgroups of G with complement ⟨a⟩ intersect ⟨a⟩ trivially? The case where all groups ⟨a, bg⟩, g ∈ G, are finite is of special interest.
V. P. Shunkov
answer:
No, in general case not necessarily.
As a counter-example one can take G = ⟨x, y, z, a, b | x7 = y7 = [x, y, y] = [x, y, x] = a3 = b2 = [a, b] = 1, xa = x2, ya = y2, xb = x−1, yb = y−1⟩ with H = ⟨a, b⟩. Analogous examples exist also for p = 2 and every odd prime q (A. I. Sozutov, Letter of 2002).
